Forecasts from ten experts on whether the IMF and Lebanon will announce an agreement before July 1, 2025, cluster mostly between 35% and 43%, with two notable outliers above 60%. Across perspectives—ranging from IMF negotiation procedure experts, sovereign debt advisors, international political economists, IR theorists, and Middle East studies specialists—there is broad consensus on key factors. All emphasize Lebanon’s dire economic need and a visible recent uptick in high-level technical meetings, legislative progress, and public political will, which moderately raise the probability of a deal compared to past cycles. However, nearly all highlight Lebanon’s entrenched political fragmentation, poor reform implementation history, and legislative/bureaucratic bottlenecks as major obstacles. The short time window (1 month) and the IMF’s usual insistence on credible, implemented reforms are seen as strong constraints, limiting the chance for a finalized and public money-providing agreement within the deadline.

Some experts argue that the unusual urgency (post-conflict, reconstruction needs, intense international pressure) plus exceptional recent signals could enable a minimal, possibly phased or staff-level agreement—thus justifying probabilities modestly above base rates (35%-43%). A few (notably those emphasizing international leverage, external patronage, and last-minute brinkmanship tendencies) judge the probability considerably higher (62%, 65%, 70%), emphasizing the strong incentives for all sides to avoid collapse and announce something before July 1, perhaps with the IMF accepting minimum reforms or a conditional first tranche.

No expert rates a Yes outcome as a certainty; all caution that risks of last-minute political blockage, elite collusion, or IMF insistence on true reform could still scuttle the deal. The most common scenario for No is ongoing technical progress but failure to get core reforms passed; for Yes, a compressed effort succeeds in enacting just enough legal and technical change for an announcement before the deadline.

Summary judgment: While nearly all experts see higher chances than historical norm, the modal forecast is just below even odds, recognizing deep Lebanese institutional inertia and IMF caution, offset by exceptional present urgency. The probability range is 35%-43% for most, with a minority at 62%-70%, and the overall consensus is one of high uncertainty but meaningful (though sub-50% or at-best-even) chances for a Yes.
